title: 108_hr2913
content: The Act may be cited as the "Distance Education and Online Learning Act of 2003". Student eligibility is addressed in the Act. The Act, titled "Distance Education and Online Learning Act of 2003", addresses student eligibility by amending Section 484(l)(1) of the Higher Education Act of 1965. It modifies the requirements for institutions of higher education and defines eligible programs. Section 481(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for distance education programs that are approved by recognized accrediting agencies for eligibility under the Act. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for distance education programs approved by recognized accrediting agencies. Institutions offering these programs must comply with specific criteria based on certification duration, including not having participation limitations in the past five years. In the preceding 5 years, institutions must not have unresolved audit findings requiring repayment of over 5% of total funds received under authorized programs. Additionally, they must not have been found by the Secretary to have issues in the past 5 years. In the preceding 5 years, institutions must not have unresolved audit findings requiring repayment of over 5% of total funds received under authorized programs. They must also not be in material noncompliance with the provisions related to audit reports or be determined financially responsible under regulations. Institutions participating in programs under this title for less than four years must meet specific requirements, including not being subject to any actions that would suspend, revoke, withdraw, or terminate their authority to operate by a state or their accreditation. Institutions must not have committed fraud or violations of law involving government funds, and individuals in control must not be affiliated with institutions that have lost accreditation. Institutions facing denial of accreditation, loss of operating authority, bankruptcy, or closure due to program liabilities may face consequences such as withdrawal of approval by the accreditation agency. If an institution faces denial of accreditation, loss of operating authority, bankruptcy, or closure due to program liabilities, and fails to meet requirements, the program will no longer be eligible until approval is obtained or the failure is corrected. SEC. 4. RECOGNITION OF ACCREDITING AGENCY OR ASSOCIATION. Section 496 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include accreditation of institutions offering distance education programs within the scope of recognition for agencies or associations that meet the requirements. Education programs seeking accreditation for distance education must demonstrate measures of student achievement, program completion rates, faculty and student preparation, interaction quality, and learning resources availability. The accreditation criteria for distance education programs include student achievement measures, program completion rates, faculty and student preparation, interaction quality, learning resources availability, and integrity of student and faculty participation.
